Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 39542 
Regional Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2008 
 
 
 
 
Accelerating the Implementation of the  
Core Agriculture Support Program 
(Cofinanced by the Government of the People's Republic of China) 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AINS  –  Agriculture Information Network Service 
ANR  –  agriculture and natural resource 
  CASP  –  Core Agriculture Support Program 
CGIAR  –  Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research 
FAO  Food and Agriculture Organization 
  FECC  –  Foreign Economic Cooperation Center 
GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
IFAD  –  International Fund for Agricultural Development 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  RRE  –  rural renewable energy 
  TAD  –  trans-boundary animal disease 
  WGA  –  Working Group on Agriculture 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Sector  –  Agriculture and natural resources  
Subsector  –  Agriculture sector development  
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation, capacity 
development  
Subthemes  –  Addressing information and communication technology issues; 
sharing information and knowledge; institutional development 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  A. Thapan, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  U. Malik, Agriculture, Environment, and Natural Resources Division, 
SERD 
   
Team leader   M. Ahmed, Senior Agricultural Economist, SERD 
Team members  I. Makin, Senior Water Resources Management Specialist, SERD 
  S. Setboonsarng, Senior Agricultural Economist, SERD 
M. Drilon, Natural Resources Economist, SERD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  April  2007,  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Agriculture  Ministers’  Meeting 
endorsed  the  Strategic  Framework  for  Subregional  Cooperation  in  Agriculture  and  the  Core 
Agriculture Support Program (CASP) for 2006–2010.1 The CASP consists of priority projects under 
five strategic components designed to sustain and further accelerate cooperation in agriculture: (i) 
facilitating cross-border agricultural trade and investment, (ii) promoting public-private partnerships 
in sharing agricultural information, (iii) enhancing capacity in agricultural science and technology, 
(iv) establishing emergency response mechanisms for agricultural and natural resource crises, and 
(v) strengthening institutional linkages and mechanisms for cooperation. At their third summit, held 
on 31 March 2008 in Vientiane, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, GMS leaders were greatly 
encouraged by the concrete results delivered by the GMS program.  In agriculture, the leaders 
recognized current initiatives to promote cross-border agricultural trade, ensure food safety, and 
improve farmers’ livelihoods. In their Joint Summit Declaration, the leaders gave explicit directives 
on the immediate focus of agricultural cooperation, specifically (i) implementing the GMS initiative 
on rural renewable energy (RRE) development; (ii) expanding control programs for trans-boundary 
animal  diseases,  and  (iii)  supporting  access  to  agricultural  information  in  rural  areas.  These 
concerns are incorporated in the priority projects under the CASP and the Vientiane Plan of Action 
for GMS Development (2008–2012), 2 which was endorsed during the Third GMS Summit. 
2.  Under regional technical assistance (RETA) for the Expansion of Subregional Cooperation 
in Agriculture in the Greater Mekong Subregion,3 support was provided to (i) establish a secretariat 
of the Working Group on Agriculture (WGA) to provide technical backstopping for GMS WGA 
activities; (ii) organize key meetings and workshops; (iii) develop the Strategic Framework for 
Subregional Cooperation in Agriculture and the CASP; (iv) establish the Agriculture Information 
Network Service (AINS); and (v) conduct studies and consultations on bioenergy development in 
the  GMS,  including  a  preliminary  assessment  of  strategies  and  options  for  GMS  RRE 
development.  Under  RETA  6324,  a  WGA  National  Coordinator  has  been  appointed  in  each 
participating GMS country. This RETA, which is a follow-up of RETA 6324, will establish a WGA 
National Secretariat in each country composed of a WGA National Coordinator and Support Staff. 
RETA 6324 is expected to be completed by June 2009. This follow-up RETA is crucial in further 
accelerating the implementation of the CASP and initiatives under the Vientiane Plan of Action.  
3.  The Fact-Finding Mission for the RETA was done during staff visits to the GMS countries 
and through a collective consultation with the member countries and key development partners at 
the fifth meeting of the WGA (WGA-5).4 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The Strategic Framework for Subregional Cooperation in Agriculture 2006–2010 identified a 
number of issues and challenges regarding GMS cooperation in agriculture. There is a need to 
intensify efforts under the CASP to help address emerging global concerns, including climate 
change, rising food prices, water security, and rising rural energy demand. In view of volatile food, 
energy, and input prices, there is an urgent need to prioritize areas of further cooperation among 
GMS countries to ensure subregional food security. An effective agricultural strategy involves 
optimizing outputs and benefits from agriculture through the implementation of biotechnology and 
biosafety  policies  and  developing  new  areas  in  agriculture  through  renewable  energy  crops. 
Information and technology on these and other areas of agriculture can be disseminated and 
shared in the GMS through AINS, established under RETA 6324. Similarly, cross-border trade and 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2007. Strategic Framework for Subregional Cooperation in Agriculture 2006–2010. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2008. Greater Mekong Subregion Vientiane Plan of Action. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Expansion of Subregional Cooperation in Agriculture in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (Cofinanced by the Government of the People’s Republic of China). Manila (TA 6324-REG). 
4  The WGA-5 meeting was held on 22–24 September 2008 in Vientiane.

2   
contract farming can stimulate agricultural investments and significantly contribute to achieving 
food  security  in  the  subregion.  Regional  cooperation  and  integration,  one  of  the  five  core 
specializations that the Asian Development Bank (ADB)5 will focus on, is an effective instrument for 
accelerating economic growth, reducing poverty, raising productivity, and strengthening institutions.    
5.   Application  of  Advanced  Science  and  Technology.  The recent food crisis affected 
millions of households in Asia and highlighted agriculture’s strategic role in poverty reduction. The 
application of advanced agricultural science and technology, including biotechnology and biosafety, 
provides opportunities for the GMS to harness the subregion’s agro-biodiversity to sustainably 
improve agricultural production and its safety standards to strengthen food security and contribute 
to poverty alleviation.  
6.   Role of Rural Renewable Energy. The broader use of RRE sources, especially biomass, 
biogas, biodiesel, and bioethanol, is seen as an important option to meet energy demand in rural 
areas, mitigate environmental problems, and help to spur growth in agriculture and the rural sector. 
Modern bioenergy offers a promising alternative to traditional fuels such as firewood and charcoal. 
The  WGA  recently  concluded  a  preliminary  assessment  of  strategies  and  options  for  RRE 
development in the GMS and prepared a draft framework for it.6 For GMS countries, developing a 
national strategy for RRE development is crucial in helping governments and policymakers make 
informed decisions, especially in light of diverse findings on energy crops and their implications for 
food security. 
7.   Enhancing Food Security through Cross-Border Trade. Soaring prices for food, energy, 
and agricultural inputs will require a strategic GMS response and enhanced cooperation among 
GMS countries to ensure subregional food security amid the complex challenges posed by climate 
change. This will require a common assessment framework for impacts on farmers and rural 
communities and cooperation on policy, information, and technology to accelerate the medium-
term  growth  of  agriculture,  including  the  farming  of  alternative  sources  of  energy.  Another 
important area is facilitation of agricultural development and trade in a way that ensures the 
equitable  distribution  of  benefits.  The  GMS  program’s  development  of  economic  corridors 
contributes to increased trade and investment among GMS countries. Contract farming is seen as 
a major growth area in cross-border trade, especially in the emerging biofuel industry. Also, the 
adoption of harmonized sanitary and phytosanitary standards for agricultural products to facilitate 
intraregional  trade  is  an  important  area  of  focus.  The  AINS  website  will  enable  the  efficient 
exchange of information between suppliers and traders of agricultural products. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The  RETA7 will  enable  the  WGA  to  respond  to  the  priority  needs  identified  in  GMS 
countries during the Third GMS Summit. It will further contribute to efforts to strengthen food and 
energy security, while addressing the challenge of climate change in the subregion. It has five 
major components: (i) component 1: biotechnology and biosafety; (ii) component 2: AINS; (iii) 
component 3: rural renewable energy development; (iv) component 4: food security and cross-
border agricultural trade and investment; and (v) component 5: regional cooperation. 
 
                                                 
5 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank 2008–2020. Manila. 
6 The RRE initiative in the GMS was formally launched during the Planning Workshop on Strategies and Options for 
Integrating Biofuels and Rural Renewable Energy for Poverty Reduction on 11–13 June 2007 in Bangkok, Thailand. 
An outline of the regional strategic framework for RRE development was endorsed during the WGA-5 meeting by GMS 
national coordinators. 
7  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 September 2008.

3
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The main impact of the RETA is an agriculture sector in the GMS that is more integrated 
and  consistent  with  the  goal  of  CASP.  The  expected  outcome  is  enhanced  GMS  regional 
cooperation and investment in CASP. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The RETA will have five main outputs: (i) implementation of the strategy for biotechnology 
and  biosafety  initiated,  (ii)  agriculture  information  and  network  service  development  and  use 
promoted, (iii) rural renewable energy development strategy supported, (iv) food security and 
cross-border agriculture trade strategies developed, and (v) WGA Secretariat strengthened. 
11.  Component  1:  Implementation  of  the  Strategy  for  Biotechnology  and  Biosafety 
Initiated.  The  RETA  on  Strengthening  Capacity  and  Regional  Cooperation  in  Advanced 
Agricultural Science and Technology (Phase I)8 was able to (i) increase basic awareness about 
advanced agricultural science and technology and related food safety issues among key GMS 
stakeholders, (ii) strengthen the technical capacity of relevant GMS institutions, and (iii) develop a 
subregional strategic framework and action plan for biotechnology and biosafety for the GMS.9 
Specific activities included conducting biotechnology and biosafety workshops, forums, special 
studies, and training courses for (i) strengthening capacity in GMS countries for policy formulation 
and implementation; (ii) strengthening regional cooperation on biotechnology and biosafety in the 
GMS, including the sharing of technical and human resources and the establishment of regional 
mechanisms; (iii) establishing a regional information management system for biotechnology and 
biosafety such as a web-based information gateway and platform for the GMS to complement 
AINS; and (iv) enhancing the capacity in GMS countries to safely apply non-genetically modified 
biotechnology. This component will be linked with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) 
Regional Technical Cooperation Programme (TCP) Facility on Biosafety. 
12.  Component 2: Agriculture Information and Network Service Development and Use 
Promoted. The objective of AINS is to provide access to up-to-date information on agriculture in 
the GMS to support the exchange of information and foster interregional trade in agricultural 
produce and value-added products. RETA 6324 was able to (i) establish AINS servers in each 
GMS country in national languages with content maintenance provided by national agricultural 
information services, (ii) provide capacity development for national focal points and leaders of host 
organizations, and (iii) launch the AINS website with content collated and processed by each host 
organization.  However,  the  long-term  objective  of  establishing  a  trading  platform  to  facilitate 
greater economic and trade activities in agriculture, still needs development to become operational. 
The RETA will support the maintenance and extension of the operational AINS website. It will 
enable a widening of the AINS network base and provide capacity development for the AINS 
network focal points through workshops on the use of information technology in agriculture for 
GMS member countries. It will support an annual GMS AINS coordination and planning workshop. 
Information on the CASP will be disseminated through the AINS website. The FAO will link its food 
security monitoring system to the AINS through populating critical data related to soaring food 
prices through FAO’s monthly Asia-Pacific Food Situation Update. AINS can also link up with the 
Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) distance learning and information and communication 
technology (ICT) program. 
                                                 
8  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Capacity and Regional Cooperation in Advanced Agricultural 
Science and Technology in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila (TA 6214-REG,  for $1 million, approved on 17 
December). 
9  ADB. 2008. Regional Strategic Framework and Action Plan for Biotechnology and Biosafety for the GMS (Volume I) 
and Supporting Technical Papers (Volume II). Manila.

4   
13.  Component 3: Rural Renewable Energy (RRE) Development Strategy Supported. The 
RETA will support activities in the RRE initiative, including (i) developing an implementation plan 
for the regional strategic framework on RRE development; (ii) in-depth studies and an assessment 
of conducting pilot demonstration and training activities in the People’s Republic of China (PRC); 
and (iii) workshops, surveys, seminars, and trainings in the PRC. There are significant implications 
for land use and land conversion resulting from the development of RRE crop cultivation and 
feedstock production through contract farming, as well as other means of trading land, labor, and 
capital in GMS countries. A regional approach to RRE development covering biofuels and other 
sources such as biogas and biomass will be beneficial to the GMS. The RRE initiative will have 
strong linkages to national investment plans for RRE in the GMS and selected countries in other 
regions. This component will be linked to FAO’s regional biofuels TCP on poverty reduction and 
biofuels in the GMS. 
14.  Component  4:  Food  Security  and  Cross-Border  Agricultural  Trade  Strategies 
Developed. To enhance food security and cross-border trade in the GMS, the RETA will (i) 
develop a food security strategic framework for the GMS and a regional strategy to address 
specific cross-border agricultural trade issues, including the strengthening of institutional capacity 
on food safety and sanitary and phytosanitary standards; (ii) support a comprehensive assessment 
of agriculture trade competitiveness in the GMS, including demand and supply of agricultural 
products, cross-border agriculture resource and market information systems, and an analysis of the 
costs and benefits of corridor development; and (iii) organize policy forums and dialogues. The 
WGA Secretariat will link up with (i) FAO and International Fund for Agricultural Development 
(IFAD)  joint  value  chain  development  project  that  covers  cross-border  trade  and  south-south 
cooperation in the GMS; and (ii) FAO’s TCP facility on monitoring food market development under 
its initiative for soaring food prices. 
15.  Component 5: WGA Secretariat Strengthened. In pursuit of subregional cooperation in 
agriculture, the WGA will continue to serve as the mechanism by which GMS member countries 
are  able  to  come  together,  discuss,  and  collectively  agree  on  action  programs  to  address 
subregional issues, challenges, and opportunities in agriculture. An expected output from this 
RETA is the strengthened capacity of GMS countries to coordinate and communicate on regional 
issues  and  concerns  and  to  work  together  toward  the  shared  goal  of  GMS  growth  and 
development. Through the technical coordination and facilitation of the WGA secretariat, the WGA 
will  conduct  activities  to  implement  CASP  priority  projects  and  core  activities  including  WGA 
meetings, dialogues, consultation workshops, publications, website enhancements, and studies of 
priority CASP areas. The RETA will provide opportunities for consultations with GMS countries, 
development partners, and other key stakeholders, as well as coordination with other GMS sector 
working groups, especially on common issues.  
16.  Project interventions are expected to improve agriculture and encourage socially inclusive 
development.  The  development  of  strategic  frameworks  for  components  3  and  4  will  raise 
awareness of the issues and concerns of ethnic minorities and indigenous people. The design will 
incorporate the selection criteria and identify extension, training, and capacity building needs for 
these groups. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The cost of the RETA is estimated at $3.164 million equivalent. ADB will finance the 
equivalent of $1.50 million as a grant from ADB’s TA funding program, and the equivalent of 
$500,000 will be financed as a grant by the Government of the PRC. GMS countries will contribute 
the equivalent of $250,000 in-kind. The IFAD will finance $200,000, and FAO  will contribute 
$714,000. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The  Agriculture,  Environment,  and  Natural  Resources  Division  of  the  Southeast  Asia 
Department of ADB will be the Executing Agency of the RETA through the WGA Secretariat. The 
WGA Secretariat will be responsible for coordinating RETA activities and providing technical and 
administrative support under the supervision of the designated ADB project officer. The WGA 
Secretariat will serve as the management unit for the RETA and oversee its implementation. The 
FAO, IFAD, Foreign Economic Cooperation Center (FECC) of the PRC Ministry of Agriculture, and 
the WGA National Secretariats in the GMS will be responsible for implementing the RETA. The 
FAO will implement components 1 and 3, except for activity (iii) under component 1, which will be 
implemented by the National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA). Activities 
under components 1, 2 and 3 will be linked with the Exchange and Cooperation Consortium for 
Agricultural  Science  and  Technology  in  the  GMS.  Activities  under  component  3  will  be 
complemented by the energy and environment partnership program in GMS countries supported 
by the Government of Finland. Activities under components 1 and 4 will be complemented by the 
capacity building and research programs of ADBI. Component 2 will be implemented by FECC in 
collaboration with the GMS countries. The WGA Secretariat will be responsible in coordinating with 
FAO and IFAD in implementing component 4. IFAD will conduct further assessment studies in the 
PRC under component 3. Disbursements under the RETA will be done in accordance with the 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as amended from time to time).10The 
RETA will be implemented over 3 years from June 2009 to June 2012 in collaboration with GMS 
working  groups,  especially  the  Working  Group  on  Environment.  The  project  organizational 
structure and fund flow is shown in Figure A4.2 in Appendix 4. The progress and outputs of the 
RETA will be shared with WGA members and discussed during annual meetings. A no-objection 
letter  will  be  obtained  before  starting  the  RETA  activities  in  the  territory  of  the  participating 
developing member countries. 
19.  The RETA will require 30 person-months of international consultancy including (i) a regional 
cooperation  specialist;  (ii)  subject  matter  specialists  for  components  1,  3,  and  4;  and  (iii)  a 
monitoring  and  evaluation  specialist.  National  consultants  for  42  person-months  will  be  (i)  a 
program  coordinator/regional  cooperation  specialist  and  (ii)  an  information  technology  and 
database management expert. For the regional cooperation component, ADB will finance (i) 10 
person-months from a regional cooperation specialist; (ii) 2 person-months from a monitoring and 
evaluation specialist; (iii) 6 person-months from a subject matter specialist for component 1; (iv) 6 
person-months from a subject matter specialist for component 4; and (v) 36 person-months from a 
program coordinator and regional cooperation specialist. FAO will provide 6 person-months from a 
subject matter specialist for component 3. The PRC will fund 6 person-months from an information 
technology and database management expert for component 2. The outlines of terms of reference 
for the consultants are in Appendix 3. Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Equipment will be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time) and will be handed over to implementing departments upon RETA 
completion.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the People’s Republic of China; and (ii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for Accelerating 
the Implementation of the Core Agriculture Support Program, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

national support staff. 
c  Includes $173,400 cost of three WGA meetings, and seminars and workshops on key issues and 
themes. 
d  Includes $50,000 (component 1) to establish a web-based information gateway and platform for the 
GMS by the National Science and Technology Development Agency. 
e  Includes the $190,800 budget for WGA administrative support staff inputs. 
f  Parallel financing from IFAD will cover biofuels modeling and assessment in the People’s Republic of 
China. 
g  Parallel financing from FAO will cover (i) $300,000 (component 1); (ii)$374,000 (component 3); and 
(iii) $40,000 (component 4).  
h  The in-kind contribution will cover personnel inputs and other administrative expenses. 
i  The  governments  of  Cambodia,  Viet  Nam,  Thailand,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  and 
Myanmar will provide $50,000 each as in-kind contribution. The in-kind contributions will cover office 
accommodation, counterpart support staff, and other administrative expenses.  
           Source: ADB estimates.

Appendix 3         11 
   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General Requirements 
1.  The following consulting services will be required for the regional technical assistance 
(RETA).

B.  Duties and Responsibilities of Consultants 
 
1.  International Consultants 
2.  Regional Cooperation Specialist (international, 10 person-months). The specialist will 
preferably have postgraduate training in the social sciences and possess strong report-writing, 
organizational, and leadership skills. The specialist must have experience working with Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries and be familiar with the current situation of agriculture and 
rural development. The specialist must have strong background in program management. 
3.  The specialist shall be tasked to do the following: 
(i)  Provide  senior  technical  and  advisory  support  for  activities  and  discussions 
relevant to the operations of the Working Group on Agriculture (WGA). This will 
include  reviewing  the  WGA  annual  work  program  as  well  as  designing  and

12  Appendix 3          
   
implementing selected priority activities of the Core Agriculture Support Program 
(CASP). 
(ii)  Manage  an  effective  database  to  facilitate  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the 
implementation of the subregional development road map. 
(iii)  Provide sound recommendations for funding priority projects under the CASP 
and promoting partnerships and investments in the subregion. 
(iv)  Prepare the preliminary financing and investment needs of CASP projects and 
examine possible financing options by mapping relevant external and internal 
assistance programs. 
(v)  Design the program and agenda for WGA meetings, workshops, consultations, 
and  conferences  and  facilitate  dialogue  among  GMS  countries  and  key 
stakeholders, including development partners and the private sector, on various 
issues and concerns relating to subregional cooperation in agriculture. 
(vi)  In coordination with the national regional cooperation specialist, organize and 
facilitate WGA meetings, workshops, and conferences. 
(vii)  Promote  the  dissemination  of  research  findings  of  the  regional  technical 
assistance (RETA) among GMS countries in coordination with relevant research 
institutions. 
(viii)  Follow through on implementing outcomes of subregional cooperation meetings. 
(ix)  Provide guidance to national consultants in the facilitation of networking among 
WGA coordinators and partner agencies. 
(x)  Prepare detailed concept papers, proposals for priority initiatives, and issues and 
background papers for WGA meetings, workshops, conferences, and seminars.  
(xi)  Submit reports relevant to WGA implementation of the RETA and a final report of 
RETA activities. 
 
4.  Subject  Matter  Specialists  (international,  18  person-months).  The  specialists  shall 
have extensive experience working in developing countries, particularly in the GMS, and must 
have a strong background in developing national and regional strategies and action plans. In 
addition, the specialists must have strong report-writing, organizational, and leadership skills. 
Components that will need the assistance of subject matter specialists are (i) biotechnology and 
biosafety  (6  person-months),  (ii)  rural  renewable  energy  (6  person-months),  and  (iii)  food 
security and cross-border trade (6 person-months). The required expertise will depend on the 
topics and areas for research identified.  
5.  The specialists are expected to do the following: 
(i)  Conduct a comprehensive assessment study and undertake detailed analysis of 
the assigned topic in a GMS setting. 
(ii)  Identify capacity gaps and needs and make appropriate policy recommendations. 
(iii)  Identify and recommend new areas for research. 
(iv)  Submit a comprehensive report on the assigned topic.  
(v)  Assist in revising the manuscript to conform to the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) publication format. 
 
6.  Monitoring  and  Evaluation  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
monitoring and evaluation specialist will preferably have a social science degree and possess 
strong report-writing and organizational skills. He or she should have extensive experience in 
program and project monitoring and evaluation and is expected to do the following: 
(i)  Design and develop a systematic process of monitoring and evaluation, using a 
results-focused monitoring framework for the RETA and the CASP.

Appendix 3         13 
   
(ii)  Review the work plans and timeline of activities for the CASP and the various 
components of the RETA. 
(iii)  Develop a database for results monitoring and evaluation for the CASP and the 
RETA. 
 
2.  National Consultants 
 
7.  Program Coordinator/Regional Cooperation Specialist (national, 36 person-months). 
The program coordinator will preferably have a social science degree and possess strong 
report-writing and organizational skills. The specialist must have related experience working 
with GMS countries.  
8.  The program coordinator shall be tasked to do the following: 
(i)  Provide  technical  and  administrative  support  for  activities  and  discussions 
relevant to the operations of the WGA. This will include assistance in reviewing 
the WGA annual work program as well as designing and implementing selected 
priority activities of the CASP. 
(ii)  Assist the regional cooperation specialist in designing the program and agenda 
for WGA meetings, workshops, consultations, and conferences. 
(iii)  Organize and facilitate WGA meetings, workshops, and conferences. 
(iv)  Assist in disseminating the research findings of the RETA among GMS countries 
in coordination with relevant research institutions. 
(v)  Work  in  coordination  with  WGA  focal  points  and  the  regional  cooperation 
specialist to implement subcomponents of subregional activities. 
(vi)  Assist  in  preparing  multimedia  presentations  for  WGA  meetings,  workshops, 
training seminars, and other key events. 
(vii)  Assist in preparing detailed concept papers, proposals for priority initiatives, and 
issues and background papers for WGA meetings, workshops, conferences, and 
seminars.  
(viii)  Assist in preparing reports relevant to WGA implementation of the RETA and the 
final report of RETA activities. 
 
9.  Information  Technology  and  Database  Management  Expert  (national,  6  person-
months).  The  expert  must  have  extensive  experience  in  the  design  and  development  of 
database management and information systems and strong report-writing, organizational, and 
leadership skills. He or she must be a graduate in computer science or a related field. The 
expert shall assist the Foreign Economic Cooperation Center in the following: 
(i)  Provide technical and advisory support and leadership in the conduct of short-
term studies in the GMS to collate relevant information and knowledge products 
to further populate the Agriculture Information Network Service (AINS) database.  
(ii)  Provide  technical  and  advisory  guidance  in  the  development  of  the  trading 
platform  through  the  extension  of  the  AINS  database  system,  including  the 
development and use of interoperability approaches to access services such as 
the  Food  and  Agriculture  Organization’s  AGROVOC  multilingual  database  to 
facilitate the identification of relevant information in national AINS sites and other 
agricultural information services.  
(iii)  Recommend  feasible  options  for  sustainably  financing  the  operation  and 
development of AINS websites.  
(iv)  Organize  relevant  workshops  and/or  conferences  and  coordinate  capacity 
development meetings for national focal points and the AINS development team.

14  Appendix 4            
   
CORE AGRICULTURE SUPPORT PROGRAM:  
FRAMEWORK FOR IMPLEMENTATION  
 
A.   The Core Agriculture Support Program 
 
1.  The Core Agriculture Support Program (CASP) consists of a series of priority projects 
grouped into broad subject areas (components) in the context of subregional cooperation in 
agriculture. The components seek to address issues and lead to accelerated and expanded 
subregional  cooperation  and  enhanced  agricultural  growth  and  poverty  reduction  through 
increased investments and cross-border agricultural trade. 
 
1.  Facilitating Cross-Border Agricultural Trade and Investment 
 
2.  Trade  in  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  countries  will  benefit  from  the 
coordination and establishment of wholesale agriculture markets and distribution centers in 
border  areas.  Likewise,  the  introduction  of  cross-border  agricultural  resource  and  market 
information  systems  will  open  up  opportunities  for  cross-border  cooperation  in  farming, 
processing, and value-added activities in agriculture. The Working Group on Agriculture (WGA) 
can  facilitate  through  the  CASP  the  preparation  of  principal  guidelines  or  regulations  for 
conducting foreign direct investment linked to contract farming. Also, sanitary and phytosanitary 
regulations vary among GMS countries. Enhanced cooperation toward standardizing agricultural 
produce  and  products  will  facilitate  agricultural  trade  among  GMS  countries.  The  priority 
projects and subprojects of this component cover a range of cross-border and related issues, 
including regulatory systems and standards, demand and supply, contract farming, and food 
safety.  
 
2.  Promoting Public-Private Partnerships in Sharing Agricultural Information 
 
3.  Knowledge management, intellectual capital, and information and knowledge sharing are 
essential for agricultural development. Effective mechanisms need to be established to enhance 
public-private partnership in the exchange of information for mutual benefit. This component will 
establish information- and knowledge-sharing systems that will enhance the involvement of the 
private sector in sharing intellectual capital for agriculture. The centerpiece of this component is 
the GMS Agricultural Information Network Service, a joint initiative of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Through this component, the WGA will 
work  closely  with  the  Consultative  Group  on  International  Agricultural  Research  (CGIAR), 
Centre de coopération internationale en recherche agronomique pour le développement, and 
other specialized agencies that have had initiatives on agricultural knowledge management in 
the subregion. Priority areas include improving farmers’ livelihoods through postharvest and 
information technology and developing and enhancing knowledge-sharing systems to assist 
sectoral development, both in research and development and in agricultural extension services. 
 
3.  Enhancing Capacity in Agricultural Science and Technology 
 
4.  The  WGA  will  collaborate  with  initiatives  that  build  capability  for  agricultural 
competitiveness and facilitate capacity building in agricultural water resource management. It 
will promote rural renewable energy sources, particularly the demonstration and extension of 
biogas  and  biofuel  technology.  The  WGA  will  continue  to  support  advanced  science  and 
technology undertakings in biotechnology and biofuels to integrate available technologies, both 
old and new, into farming systems and enhance the associated value chains. This component 
will explore linkages with specialized agencies, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization

Appendix 4         15 
   
(FAO) of the United Nations, on the provision of programs to build agricultural competitiveness 
in  the  subregion.  Through  regional  initiatives  in  research,  training,  and  extension,  this 
component will encourage and mobilize resources for the development of existing institutions by 
strengthening them to become centers of excellence or centers of development. The projects 
involve research, management, and/or training in such areas as renewable energy, agricultural 
extension, fisheries development, water and natural resources issues, sanitation aspects, trans-
boundary animal diseases (TADs), and quarantine. 
 
4.  Establishing  Emergency  Response  Mechanisms  for  Agricultural  and 
Natural Resources Crises 
 
5.  Subregional cooperation in agriculture needs a collective response mechanism to cope 
with agriculture-related emergencies, calamities, and natural disasters, as well as to address the 
spread of animal disease, floods, pest infestation, and forest fires, which can result in huge 
economic losses in the GMS. Through this component, a disaster preparedness, mitigation, and 
emergency response system for agricultural crises, based on geographic information systems, 
will improve the capability of the GMS countries to develop mitigation and coping strategies for 
such calamities. The WGA will coordinate with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, 
which sponsors a similar initiative among its member countries. 
 
5.  Strengthening Institutional Linkages and Mechanisms for Cooperation 
 
6.  Agricultural institutional linkages and mechanisms, operational systems, and protocols 
for the WGA need to be developed with national coordinators, in line with the thrust of the 
overall GMS program to strengthen infrastructure linkages through a multisectoral approach. 
The WGA Secretariat has been set up to assist in implementing priority projects. National 
committees and coordinating offices for the WGA will be strengthened. The component includes 
promoting partnerships in priority areas identified by the WGA, sharing best practices and 
research results, and the exchange of information with stakeholders in the private, public, and 
nongovernmental  sectors,  including  farmers,  as  well  as  with  development  partners  and 
international  centers  of  excellence.  The  component  will  provide  opportunities  for  extensive 
dialogue and forums for participatory planning, design, and knowledge dissemination. It will 
create communities of practice in the GMS countries for reducing rural poverty.  
 
B.   Status of Core Agriculture Support Program  
 
1.  Regional  Technical  Assistance  (RETA)  6324:  Expansion  of  Subregional 
Cooperation in Agriculture in the Greater Mekong Subregion10 
 
7.  Prioritization of Projects. Following endorsement of the CASP during the Agriculture 
Ministers’  Meeting  in  Beijing  in  April  2007,  projects  under  the  CASP  were  prioritized  and 
identified as short-, medium-, and long-term at the December 2007 WGA national coordinators’ 
meeting. A prioritization exercise was undertaken by the WGA to finalize the Vientiane Plan of 
Action for Agriculture. Under group 1, there are projects that are ongoing or for immediate 
implementation with identified financing. These are Policy Support for Cross-Border Contract 
Farming, Improving Farmers’ Livelihood through Postharvest Technology, Improving Farmers’ 
Livelihood  through  Rice  Information  Technology,  Agriculture  Information  Network  Service 
(AINS), GMS Rural Renewable Energy Development Project, Trans-boundary Animal Disease 
                                                 
10 ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Expansion of Subregional Cooperation in Agriculture in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion. Manila (TA 6324-REG, for $1 million, approved on 23 June).

16  Appendix 4            
   
(TAD)  Control  for  Poverty  Reduction  in  the  GMS  (Phase  II),  Expansion  of  Subregional 
Cooperation in Agriculture in the GMS, and Accelerating the Implementation of CASP. The 
priority projects identified were (i) Adoption of Regional Biosafety Standards and Strengthening 
National Institutional Capacities on Food Safety and Sanitary and Phytosanitary Standards in 
the GMS; (ii) Joint Study on Demand and Supply of Key Agricultural Products and Cross-Border 
Agriculture Resource and Market Information System; (iii) Building Capacities for Agricultural 
Competitiveness; (iv) Capacity Development in Rural Renewable Energy for Poverty Reduction 
in the GMS; (v) Establishing Livestock Identification and Tracking System for Disease Control 
and  Traceability;  and  (vi)  Establishing  a  Geographic  Information  System-based  Disaster 
Preparedness, Mitigation, and Emergency Response System for Agricultural Crises.  
 
8.  Elaboration of Project Concepts. The GMS national consultants were engaged by 
ADB to assist the GMS WGA in developing concept papers and proposals for funding for the 
priority projects in early 2008.  
 
C.   Approach to Accelerate Implementation of CASP 
 
9.  Resource  Mobilization.  In  several  WGA  meetings—WGA-4,11 Agriculture  Ministers’ 
Meeting,12 and WGA-513—a number of development partners, specifically FAO, International 
Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  (IFAD),  Finland,  and  CGIAR,  expressed  interest  in 
participating in the implementation of the CASP through parallel and complimentary financing. 
At present, the priority projects are being implemented through two RETA projects:  
 
10.   RETA on Accelerating the Implementation of the CASP. Under the RETA, five key 
areas  will  be  implemented  in  support  of  the CASP  components:  (i)  implementation  of  the 
strategy for biotechnology and biosafety initiated, (ii) agriculture information and network service 
development and use promoted, (iii) rural renewable energy development strategy supported, 
(iv)  food  security  and  cross-border  agriculture  trade  strategies  developed,  and  (v)  WGA 
Secretariat  strengthened.  The  objectives  of  the  CASP  supported  by  the  RETA  are  to  (i) 
accelerate and strengthen subregional cooperation in agriculture, (ii) contribute to food security 
and poverty reduction in the subregion, (iii) facilitate cross-border trade and investment in 
agriculture, (iv) facilitate the transfer and adoption of improved agricultural technologies, and (iv) 
develop human resources and competencies to address cross-border concerns.  
 
11.   RETA 6390: Trans-boundary Animal Disease Control for Poverty Reduction in the 
GMS14 (Phase II). RETA 6390 is ongoing RETA that commenced in March 2007 and aims to 
contribute to the larger goal of reducing poverty in poor livestock-raising communities in the 
GMS through better control of TADs, increased production of safer food, and enhanced access 
for smallholders to higher-value markets for their livestock and livestock products. It builds on 
the achievements of RETA 6192: Control of Trans-boundary Animal Diseases in the GMS 
(Phase I). RETA 6192 aimed to develop a regional cooperation framework, upgrade regional 
and national laboratories, and strengthen staff capacity in participating countries to control TADs. 
The RETA was able to conduct (i) socioeconomic surveys on the impacts of diseases on the 
livelihoods of poor farming communities, which was undertaken in the Upper and Lower Mekong 
Disease Control zones; (ii) the training of staff from participating countries in diagnostics and the 
                                                 
11  Held on 6–8 December 2006 in Siem Reap, Cambodia. 
12  Held on 9–11 April 2007 in Beijing. 
13  Held on 22–24 September 2008 in Vientiane, Lao People’s Democratic Republic. 
14 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Trans-boundary Animal Disease Control for Poverty Reduction in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion . Manila (TA 6390-REG, for $450,000, approved on 27 March,).

Appendix 4         17 
   
capacity development of regional and national diagnostic labs; and (iii) serological sample 
surveys and knowledge, attitudes and practices surveys, as well as data analysis. The specific 
CASP objective supported by this RETA is ensuring the surveillance and control of TADs to 
mitigate social and economic impacts. 
 
D.  Framework for Implementation  
 
12.  The proposed RETA for accelerating the implementation of CASP will initially support 
four main areas: (i) enhancing capacity in agriculture science and technology; (ii) promoting 
public-private  partnership  in  sharing  agricultural  information;  (iii)  facilitating  cross-border 
agricultural trade and investment; and (iv) strengthening institutional linkages and mechanisms 
for cooperation. It will be implemented in partnership with key development partners, WGA 
national coordinators, and selected centers of excellence (Figure A4.1). The complementary 
RETA 6390 will support activities under establishing Emergency Response Mechanisms for 
Agriculture and Natural Resource (ANR) Crises. 
 
 
 
13.  Responsibilities of Partners. The Agriculture, Environment, and Natural Resources 
Division of the Southeast Asia Department of ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA 
through the WGA Secretariat. The WGA Secretariat will be responsible for coordinating RETA 
activities  and  providing  technical  and  administrative  support  under  the  supervision  of  the 
designated ADB project officer. The WGA Secretariat will serve as the management unit for the 
RETA  and  oversee  the  implementation  of  activities.  The  FAO,  IFAD,  Foreign  Economic

18  Appendix 4            
   
Cooperation Center (FECC) of the PRC Ministry of Agriculture, and WGA National Secretariats 
in  the  GMS  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  RETA.  The  FAO  will  implement 
components  1  and  3  by  conducting  relevant  studies  and  organizing  policy  forums  and/or 
workshops. The National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA) will provide 
expertise for component 1 in (i) regional training and workshop facilities, (ii) establishing an 
information website, (iii) sharing and coordinating information with AINS, (iv) developing a web-
based  platform  for  sharing  and  updating  information  in  the  GMS  and  utilizing  baseline 
information  collected  through  RETA  6214,  and  (v)  establishing  an  information  gateway. 
Component 2 will be implemented by FECC in collaboration with the GMS countries. The FECC 
will organize coordination and planning workshops, training programs, and short-term studies to 
populate the AINS database. The IFAD will conduct further assessment studies and modeling 
on biofuels and rural renewable energy in the PRC under component 3 and cooperate with the 
WGA and ADB on component 4. Activities under Components 1 and 4 will be complemented by 
the capacity building and research programs of ADBI. The WGA Secretariat and FAO will lead 
the implementation of the component 4 by conducting relevant studies and organizing policy 
forums and/or workshops. The project implementation structure and fund flow is shown in 
Figure A4.2.
